title: 010 Getting a result from another Activity
By using
startActivityForResult(Intent intent, int requestCode)
c
a
https://developer.android.com/reference/android/app/Activity.html#startActivityForResult(android.content.Intent,%20int)
you can start another
Activity
c
a
https://developer.android.com/reference/android/app/Activity.html
and then receive a result from that
Activity
c
in the
onActivityResult(int requestCode, int resultCode, Intent data)
c
a
https://developer.android.com/reference/android/app/Activity.html#onActivityResult(int,%20int,%20android.content.Intent)
method. The result will be returned as an
Intent
c
a
https://developer.android.com/reference/android/content/Intent.html
. An intent can contain data via a Bundle

title: A few things you need to be aware of:

inline_content.Text: A few things you need to be aware of:

title: Data is only returned once you call
finish()
c
. You need to call
setResult()
c
before calling
finish()
c
, otherwise, no result will be returned.

inline_content.Text: Data is only returned once you call
, otherwise, no result will be returned.

title: Make sure your
Activity
c
is not using
android:launchMode="singleTask"
c
, or it will cause the
Activity
c
to run in a separate task and therefore you will not receive a result from it. If your
Activity
c
uses
singleTask
c
as launch mode, it will call
onActivityResult()
c
immediately with a result code of
Activity.RESULT_CANCELED
c

inline_content.Text: to run in a separate task and therefore you will not receive a result from it. If your
as launch mode, it will call
immediately with a result code of

title: Be careful when using
android:launchMode="singleInstance"
c
. On devices before Lollipop (Android 5.0, API Level 21), Activities will not return a result.

inline_content.Text: . On devices before Lollipop (Android 5.0, API Level 21), Activities will not return a result.

title: You can use
explicit
a
https://developer.android.com/guide/components/intents-filters.html#ExampleExplicit
or
implicit
a
https://developer.android.com/guide/components/intents-filters.html#ExampleSend
intents when you call
startActivityForResult()
c
. When starting one of your own activities to receive a result, you should use an explicit intent to ensure that you receive the expected result. An explicit
intent
c
is always delivered to its target, no matter what it contains; the
filter
c
is not consulted. But an implicit intent is delivered to a component only if it can pass through one of the component’s filters.

inline_content.Text: . When starting one of your own activities to receive a result, you should use an explicit intent to ensure that you receive the expected result. An explicit
is always delivered to its target, no matter what it contains; the
is not consulted. But an implicit intent is delivered to a component only if it can pass through one of the component’s filters.
